newsitem.title: CANADA: Toronto stocks end slightly down ahead of U.S. data.
newsitem.headline: Toronto stocks end slightly down ahead of U.S. data.

text.p: Toronto stocks slipped 13.13 points on Monday to close at 6537.47 on broad-based selling, as 11 of the Toronto Stock Exchange's 14 sub-indexes fell.
Trading was thin, with 31.3 million shares worth $1.01 billion changing hands. Declines outpaced advances 519 to 433, with 322 issues unchanged.
Banks, led by Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, were among the few gaining sectors, while golds, metals and forest products led the decliners.

Traders said the market is jittery ahead of U.S. consumer prices data for May, which is due out on Tuesday. Lower-than-expected consumer prices would add to the speculation that the Federal Reserve is not likely to raise rates at the monetary policy meeting July 1-2.
A Reuter survey of economists has forecast that May CPI will show a rise of 0.2 percent.

Last week's softer-than-expected U.S. producer price index and retail sales data added to the speculation that a rate increase was unlikely. But some analysts have cautioned that Federal Reserve members have warned that the U.S. central bank will seek to pre-empt a rise in inflationary pressure in the U.S. economy rather than react to one.
"If they are going to be anticipatory, they'll be moving before we have any clear evidence that inflation is emerging," said Roy Palmer, analyst with TD Securities.

In individual issues Bombardier Corp. said today it won a $209.2 million Boeing Co. contract. The airplane maker is expected to announce later this week a $1.2 billion order from AMR Corp. for 67 of its 50-seat regional jets.

Stampeder Exploration Ltd. announced a stock offering and a big increase in spending. Stampeder said it planned to use the proceeds of its offering to fund stepped up heavy oil drilling and not takeovers.
